If we ran down the list of 0E0 programs there is
not one item that could not benefit from having
access to the mass communications media. Uti¬
lizing these media takes courage, imagination,
and skill, and there is no dearth of those ele¬
ments in 0E0. What is lacking is only the oppor¬
tunity.
We have dealt, thus far, with divisional concerns,
and with the technical resolution of the problem
of transposing the classroom experience into tele¬
vision terms. We turn now to those problems in¬
herent in developing "software" materials, those
texts and guides which make learning by electronic
communications media meaningful. There are two
things which command our attention. First, is the
fact that a tremendous amount of completed ma¬
terials already exists. The techniques for pro¬
ducing these kinds of materials has not changed
appreciably since the first, education-oriented,
materials were produced. What has changed is how
we think about the materials, how we see the prob¬
lems of education, now.
